content:
Hello, it's nice to meet you. I'm a counselor and I'm here to support you on your journey. Let's start with a casual chat - what would you like to share with me today?

>>[initial relationship]

Hello, thank you for having me here. To be honest, I’ve been feeling a bit overwhelmed lately, and I’m not entirely sure where to start. I guess… life just feels a little out of balance. There’s a lot going on with my family, my work, and even just how I feel about myself. I thought it might help to talk to someone about it.

I hear that feeling of being overwhelmed - when everything seems to be happening all at once. It takes courage to reach out when things feel out of balance. Would you like to tell me more about what's been on your mind lately?

>>[initial relationship]
(Note: Providing a gentle, accepting space for the client to share while acknowledging their step to seek support)

Thank you, I appreciate that. Well, I guess a big part of it is my family situation. I’m married, and we have two kids—both under the age of five—so life at home is… chaotic, to say the least. My partner and I both work full-time, and it feels like we’re constantly juggling responsibilities.  On top of that, I’ve been feeling this growing sense of guilt, like I’m not doing enough for my kids or my partner. And then there’s work—it’s been really stressful lately, with deadlines piling up. I’ve been having trouble sleeping, and I feel like I’m running on empty most days.  It’s like I’m trying to keep everything together, but I’m not sure how much longer I can keep going like this. Does that make sense?

*Gently nodding* Yes, it makes perfect sense. You're carrying so many responsibilities - being a parent to young children, maintaining a career, trying to be there for your partner - all while dealing with sleep difficulties. It sounds exhausting. When you say you're "running on empty," I can really hear how depleted you're feeling.

If you're comfortable sharing, what kind of support are you hoping to find in our conversations together?

>>[initial relationship]
(Note: Acknowledging their experience while gently exploring their expectations for counseling)

Thank you for saying that—it feels good to have someone really hear me. I think what I’m hoping for is… clarity, maybe? I feel like I’m constantly pulled in so many directions, and I don’t know how to prioritize or even where to start.  I’d like to figure out how to manage everything without feeling like I’m failing in one area or another. I also want to understand why I feel so guilty all the time, even when I know I’m doing my best.  And honestly, I just want to feel like myself again. Right now, it’s like I’m just going through the motions, and I miss feeling present and connected—to my kids, my partner, and even to myself. Does that make sense?

It makes perfect sense. I hear your deep desire to feel more present and connected again, rather than just going through the motions. And that wish for clarity - to find your way through all these competing demands - that's such an important goal.

On a scale of 1-10, how would you say these feelings of being overwhelmed and disconnected are impacting your daily life right now? 

>>[problem exploration]
(Note: Moving to problem exploration as we've established trust and have a clear understanding of their expectations - seeking clarity, better management of responsibilities, and reconnection with self and family)

Hmm… I’d say it’s probably around an 8. Most days, it feels like I’m just barely keeping my head above water. The mornings are especially hard—getting the kids ready, thinking about work, and trying to stay on top of everything feels like a race I’m always losing.  By the time the day is over, I’m so drained that I don’t have the energy to really engage with my partner or even take care of myself. It’s like I’m stuck in this cycle, and I don’t know how to break out of it. So yeah, I’d say it’s pretty high—definitely an 8.

Thank you for being so open about this. An 8 is quite significant - it really shows how much this is affecting your daily life. Before we explore this further, I'm curious... have there been any moments, even brief ones, when things felt a little more manageable? When that feeling of being overwhelmed wasn't quite as intense?

>>[exception exploration]
(Note: Moving to exception exploration to identify potential resources and coping strategies that may already exist in their life)

That’s a good question… I think there have been a few moments like that. For example, on the weekends, when we take the kids to the park or just spend time outside as a family, I sometimes feel a little lighter. Watching them play and laugh reminds me of what’s really important, and for a little while, I can let go of the stress.  Also, there have been a couple of evenings when my partner and I managed to sit down together after the kids went to bed—just to talk or watch a show. Those moments felt nice, like we were reconnecting, even if it was just for a short time.  But honestly, those moments feel rare. It’s like they get overshadowed by everything else that’s going on.

Those moments at the park and quiet evenings with your partner sound really precious. It's beautiful how being present with your family can help lift some of that heaviness. What do you think makes these moments different? What allows you to feel more connected during these times?

>>[exception exploration]
(Note: Exploring the conditions that create these positive moments to potentially expand them)

I think it’s because, in those moments, I’m not trying to juggle a million things at once. At the park, for example, I’m just there with my kids—watching them, playing with them. I’m not thinking about work deadlines or the pile of laundry waiting at home. It’s like I can just be in the moment, and that feels really freeing.  And with my partner, those quiet evenings feel different because we’re actually spending time together, not just passing each other while dealing with the kids or chores. It’s like we’re on the same page again, even if it’s just for a little while.  I think what makes those moments stand out is that everything slows down, and I’m not trying to do everything all at once. It’s just… simpler. Peaceful, even. I wish I could hold onto that feeling more often.

Those peaceful moments seem to come when you're able to be fully present - whether it's watching your kids play or sharing quiet time with your partner. If we could create more of these moments in your life, what would that look like? What small changes might help make that possible?

>>[goal construction]
(Note: Building on these positive experiences to help construct achievable goals that align with what matters most to them)

That’s an interesting thought… I think creating more of those moments would mean finding ways to slow down and let go of the constant pressure to be “doing” all the time. Maybe it’s about carving out specific times where I can focus on just one thing—like truly being with my kids or having uninterrupted time with my partner.  For example, I could set aside a certain part of the weekend where I don’t worry about chores or work and just focus on family time, like going to the park or doing something fun together. And maybe during the week, I could try to create a routine with my partner—like having 20 or 30 minutes after the kids go to bed where we sit down together, without phones or distractions, just to talk or relax.  I think another small change could be learning to say “no” more often or setting better boundaries, especially with work. I tend to take on too much, and I think that’s part of what’s draining me. If I could protect my time a little better, I might feel less stretched so thin.  It’s hard to imagine making all of this happen, but even small steps in that direction feel like they could make a difference.

I love how you're already identifying specific, manageable changes - like dedicated family time on weekends and creating a evening routine with your partner. These sound like meaningful steps toward what matters most to you. Let's focus on one small change to start with - which of these ideas feels most doable to you right now?

>>[solution construction]
(Note: Moving to constructing concrete solutions, starting with the most achievable change to build confidence and momentum)

Thank you—that feels encouraging to hear. I think the evening routine with my partner feels the most doable right now. It’s a small step, and it doesn’t require a lot of time or planning, but I think it could make a big difference in how connected we feel.  Even just setting aside 20 minutes after the kids are in bed—no phones, no distractions—sounds like something we could realistically commit to. It feels like a good starting point, and maybe once we get into that habit, it’ll make it easier to tackle some of the bigger changes.

That's a wonderful choice - 20 minutes of undistracted time with your partner sounds like a meaningful way to reconnect. Let's make this plan more concrete. What would help make these evening moments successful? For example, what time would work best, and how might you and your partner ensure this time stays protected?

>>[solution construction]
(Note: Helping to develop specific, actionable steps while considering potential obstacles and solutions)

That’s a great idea—making it more concrete will definitely help. I think we could aim for around 8:30 or 9:00 p.m., after the kids are asleep and we’ve had a chance to tidy up or finish any immediate tasks. That feels like a time when we can both take a breather without feeling rushed.  To help protect this time, I think it would be important for us to agree on it together—so we’re both committed. Maybe we could even treat it like an appointment, something that’s non-negotiable unless there’s an emergency.  It might also help to set some boundaries, like putting our phones in another room or turning off the TV unless we’re intentionally watching something together. And we could keep it simple—just talking, having a cup of tea, or even sitting quietly together. The key would be to make it feel like quality time, not just another “to-do.”  Does that sound like a good plan? Or is there anything else I should consider to make it stick?

This sounds like a wonderfully thought-out plan! You've considered timing, removing distractions, and making it feel special but manageable. Would you be comfortable trying this for a week and seeing how it goes? Sometimes starting with a short trial period can make new habits feel less overwhelming.

>>[progress evaluation]
(Note: Moving to evaluate progress as we have a clear solution plan, setting up a way to track its effectiveness)

That’s a great idea—a week feels very manageable, and it gives us a chance to see how it works without too much pressure. I like the idea of treating it as a trial period because if it doesn’t go perfectly, we can adjust instead of feeling like we’ve failed.  I’ll talk to my partner about it and see if we can both commit to this for the next week. I’ll also try to remind myself that it doesn’t have to be perfect—it’s more about showing up and being intentional.  Thank you for helping me break this down into something that feels doable. I’m actually looking forward to trying it! I’ll let you know how it goes—hopefully, it’ll be a good first step toward feeling more connected.

I'm really moved by your enthusiasm and realistic approach! Before we wrap up today, let's quickly review: your goal is to create more connection through 20-minute evening check-ins with your partner, starting with a one-week trial. On a scale of 1-10, how confident do you feel about trying this plan?

>>[progress evaluation]
(Note: Assessing confidence level and readiness to implement the solution while maintaining the warm, supportive atmosphere we've established)

I'm really moved by your enthusiasm and realistic approach! Before we wrap up today, let's quickly review: your goal is to create more connection through 20-minute evening check-ins with your partner, starting with a one-week trial. On a scale of 1-10, how confident do you feel about trying this plan?

I appreciate your honesty - an 8 shows you're feeling optimistic while staying realistic. You've made such thoughtful progress today - from feeling overwhelmed to creating a specific, manageable plan for reconnecting with your partner. Would you like to meet again next week to see how this evening routine experiment goes?

>>[consolidation]
(Note: Moving to consolidation as we've identified clear progress and want to ensure continued support for implementing the changes)

Thank you so much for saying that—it really helps to hear! I’d love to meet again next week to check in. Having that accountability and support would be really helpful, especially as I try to stick with this new routine.  I’m looking forward to seeing how it goes and sharing what worked (or what didn’t). Thank you for helping me take this first step—it already feels like progress!

Your enthusiasm is wonderful! Before we wrap up, let's make sure you feel prepared. What might be some challenges that could come up with this evening routine, and how could you handle them? For example, if one night doesn't go as planned, what would be a kind way to get back on track the next day?

>>[consolidation]
(Note: Helping to anticipate potential obstacles and develop coping strategies to maintain progress)

That’s such a thoughtful question—thank you for helping me think ahead. I think one challenge could be if we’re both really tired or if the kids have a rough evening and we just feel drained. On those nights, it might be tempting to skip it and just zone out.  To handle that, I think it would help to remind myself that even a shorter check-in—like 5 or 10 minutes—still counts. It doesn’t have to be perfect or long to be meaningful. And if we do end up missing a night, I want to be kind to myself and not let it derail the whole plan. I could just remind myself that it’s okay to start fresh the next day and that one missed night doesn’t mean we’ve failed.  Another challenge might be distractions, like one of us getting caught up on our phones or with chores. To handle that, I think we could agree ahead of time to put our phones away and let non-urgent tasks wait until after our time together.  I think the key will be staying flexible and focusing on progress, not perfection. If I can keep that mindset, I’ll feel more motivated to keep going, even if things don’t go exactly as planned. Does that sound like a good approach?

That's excellent planning! Your approach of "progress over perfection" and having flexible backup options shows real wisdom. You've got a solid strategy: shorter check-ins when needed, phones away, and self-compassion if things don't go as planned. 

Shall we set up our next meeting to discuss how this goes? Remember, every small step toward connection counts.

>>[termination]
(Note: Moving to schedule follow-up while reinforcing the progress made and strategies developed)
